item.title: A Swath of Bank Customer Data Was Hacked. The F.B.I. Is Investigating.
item.description: SitusAMC, a technology vendor for real estate lenders, holds sensitive personal information on the clients of hundreds of its banking customers, including JPMorgan Chase.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland, Stacy Cowley and Devlin Barrett
item.media:description: JPMorgan Chase was among the banks notified by SitusAMC that its client data may have been breached.

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Takes Flight at Box Office, Expected to Make Over $150 Million
item.description: The movie is expected to take in about $151.5 million from Friday through Sunday, earning 35 percent more than the first installment last year.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Cast members at the premiere of “Wicked: For Good” in New York on Monday. Its opening weekend was the second biggest of the year.

item.title: A.I. Toy Bear Speaks of Sex, Knives and Pills, Consumer Group Warns
item.description: The chatter left startled adults unsure whether they heard correctly. Testers warned that interactive toys like this one could allow children to stray into inappropriate exchanges.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:description: A screen shot of the FoloToy website, advertising its A.I.-enabled stuffed bear, named Kumma.

item.title: The Rise of the ‘Just in Case’ M.R.I.
item.description: A growing batch of companies give customers access to whatever medical tests they want — no doctor’s orders required.
item.dc:creator: Brent Crane

item.title: Daily Mail Owner Agrees to Buy The Telegraph, Consolidating Right-Leaning Media in Britain
item.description: The deal would combine two of the country’s major newspaper groups, a move likely to attract antitrust scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Copies of British newspaper The Telegraph.

item.title: The A.I. Boom Is Driving the Economy. What Happens if It Falters?
item.description: A windfall for companies that build data centers and their suppliers is overshadowing weakness in other industries.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Sydney Ember

item.title: Miss Piggy, Fraggles and an Auction at the Twilight of a Hollywood Era
item.description: The Jim Henson Company sold its longtime studio and is auctioning Muppets memorabilia for the first time in its 70-year history.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Michelle Groskopf
item.media:description: Miss Piggy’s shoes from “The Great Muppet Caper” could go for $7,000 or “Hi-yah!”

item.title: Retiring Before (or After) Your Partner? How to Navigate Money Issues
item.description: Too many couples have “undiscussed assumptions” about how they’ll live and spend once they leave the work force, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Tammy LaGorce
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeffrey and Diane Holtaway planned for him to retire first, but the first years were trickier than expected.

item.title: What to Know About the Nearly 10% Climb in a Key Medicare Expense for 2026
item.description: The rapidly rising premium for Part B, which covers retirees’ outpatient services, reflects the fast pace of growth for health care costs nationally.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Next year is the first time the standard premium for Medicare Part B will exceed $200 a month.

item.title: Tyson Foods to Shut Major Beef Facility in Nebraska
item.description: The processing plant, in Lexington, employs more than 3,000 workers. It is expected to close in January.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Kent Sievers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tyson said on its latest earnings call that it expected operating losses on beef to be between $400 million and $600 million over the coming fiscal year.

item.title: Shoppers, Tell Us About Customs Duties on Items Bought From Overseas
item.description: It’s gift-giving season, and we want to speak to people in the United States who are buying items from other countries.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A FedEx driver making deliveries in Miami Beach.

item.title: What the Jobs Report Tells Us About the Economy
item.description: What does the September jobs report, delayed by six weeks because of the government shutdown, say about the economy? Lydia DePillis, our economics reporter, describes how the report, which was better than expected, comes at a moment of deep uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis, Claire Hogan, Stephanie Swart, Gabriel Blanco and Jacqueline Gu

item.title: Burt Meyer, 99, Dies; Made Lite-Brite and Rock ’Em Sock ’Em Robots
item.description: Starting in the 1960s, he collaborated on the designs of classic toys like Mouse Trap, Toss Across and Mr. Machine.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Strong National Museum of Play (Rochester, NY)
item.media:description: Burt Meyer in an undated photo. “There was a little mischievousness in him,” another toymaker said. “He was joyful and playful, like a kid, and treated toy design as an art form.”

item.title: Tell Us How You Watch TV and Movies
item.description: The New York Times wants to learn more about how viewing habits are evolving.
item.dc:creator: John Koblin, Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

item.title: Judge Places Hold on IRS Data Sharing With ICE
item.description: A judge halted a federal deportation effort Friday, writing that the tax agency had illegally disseminated the data of some migrants.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal judge said that the I.R.S. plan to share information with ICE was too broad.

item.title: Eli Lilly, Drug Maker of Zepbound and Mounjaro, Reaches $1 Trillion in Value
item.description: The 150-year-old drugmaker is the first company in health care to hit the milestone.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Eli Lilly, based in Indianapolis, has surged in large part because of the company’s success in commanding the GLP-1 weight loss drug market.

item.title: Sean Duffy Asks Travelers to ‘Bring Civility Back’ to Airports in New PSA
item.description: The secretary of transportation kicked off a new civility campaign on Wednesday called “The Golden Age of Travel Starts With You.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy

item.title: Thousands of French Brands Sue Shein, Accusing It of Unfair Competition
item.description: The class-action lawsuit is the latest push against the Chinese retailer in France, where protests outside its first store broke out earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:description: Shein opened its first physical space within Le BHV Marais department store in early November.

item.title: Top Fed Official Boosts Odds of a December Rate Cut
item.description: John C. Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the central bank had scope to lower borrowing costs “in the near term.”
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:description: John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

item.title: Buying a House Is Expensive. But There Are Some Ways to Rein In Costs.
item.description: The Trump administration has proposed 50-year and “portable” mortgages to make home buying more affordable. But housing experts offer other suggestions.
item.dc:creator: Ann Carrns
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)

item.title: The Fed, Crypto and A.I. Weigh on the Markets
item.description: Growing jitters over the Federal Reserve, crypto and the future of the artificial intelligence boom have helped drive a global sell-off.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:description: The recent sell-off in crypto and tech stocks has rattled global markets.

item.title: Roblox Rolls Out Face Scans for Age Verification: What to Know
item.description: The popular gaming platform said the tool was designed to stop children from chatting with older users they didn’t know.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Roblox has begun implementing a new age verification system.

item.title: Why ‘Surveillance Pricing’ Strikes a Nerve
item.description: The practice is at the intersection of two things people hate: feeling watched and feeling ripped off.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley

item.title: A Tap-to-Pay Society Is Leaving These New Yorkers Behind
item.description: As fewer people carry cash, vendors, street performers and people experiencing homelessness and unemployment are at a disadvantage.
item.dc:creator: Anna Kodé and Daniel Arnold

item.title: Uneasiness Over A.I. Spending Looms Over Markets
item.description: After stocks briefly rallied on Nvidia’s strong earnings, investors’ growing concerns of an A.I. bubble have returned, driving broad market swings.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison, River Akira Davis and Eshe Nelson

item.title: Netflix, Comcast and Paramount Submit Warner Bros. Discovery Bids
item.description: The outcome of the sale could alter the trajectory of the entertainment business.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Lauren Hirsch and Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: The studio in Burbank, Calif., could be included in a deal for Warner Bros. Discovery that Netflix, Paramount and Comcast are seeking.

item.title: Ward Landrigan, Jeweler to the Stars, Dies at 84
item.description: At Sotheby’s, he provided famous diamonds to Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton before reviving Verdura, a venerable jewelry company founded by a Sicilian duke.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Through his jewelry house Verdura, Ward Landrigan catered to high-society figures as well as celebrities like Brooke Shields, Sofia Coppola and the fashion designer Carolina Herrera.

item.title: Trump Calling Reporter ‘Piggy’ Was ‘Frankness,’ White House Says
item.description: Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, addressed for the first time a schoolyard insult that President Trump lobbed at a Bloomberg News reporter last week.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, was asked to explain what the president had meant when he called a reporter “piggy.”

item.title: U.S. Manufacturers to Benefit as GE Appliances Shifts Production
item.description: The company, now owned by a Chinese conglomerate, is investing $150 million in 19 American suppliers across 10 states.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman
item.media:description: Assembly at a GE Appliances plant in Louisville, Ky., in August. The company on Thursday announced contracts with suppliers in 10 states, as part of an effort to bring production back to U.S. soil.

item.title: Botulism Bacteria Found in Infant Formula, ByHeart Confirms
item.description: ByHeart, the maker of the product, has been linked to an outbreak of illnesses among infants that led to their hospitalizations.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A container of ByHeart’s recently recalled baby formula.

item.title: Superman Comic Sets Auction Record, Selling for $9.12 Million
item.description: A family’s forgotten copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was sold by Heritage Auctions.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.media:description: A high-grade copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was discovered by a family last year and sold for $9.12 million at auction.

item.title: Senate Democrats Investigate Kennedy Center Deals With Trump Allies
item.description: Under Richard Grenell, the performing arts center has given steep discounts to CPAC and FIFA, signed contracts with administration associates and spent lavishly on friends.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: Richard Grenell at a White House dinner for the Kennedy Center board in May. Since he was tapped to lead the center, it has become something resembling a private club for the president’s friends and supporters.

item.title: September Jobs Report Injects More Uncertainty Into Fed’s December Decision
item.description: Policymakers at the central bank are at odds over the need to cut interest rates for a third straight meeting, as inflation picks up again and the labor market slows down.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Incomplete data has major implications for the Federal Reserve officials debating whether to lower interest rates again.

item.title: Job Gains Disguise Weakness Beyond Service Industries
item.description: The unemployment rate rose in September as more people looked for jobs, according to data delayed by the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: This report will be the last one until mid-December.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Colby Smith

item.title: Did Nvidia Do Enough to Chill A.I. Bubble Fears?
item.description: The chipmaker at the center of the artificial intelligence boom reported blowout results. But that hasn’t resolved some key questions behind the tech rally.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:description: Jensen Huang, Nvidia’s C.E.O., told jittery investors that he sees no sign of an A.I. bubble.

item.title: Walmart Sales Rise as Shoppers Look For Savings
item.description: The retailer increased its guidance for the year, anticipating more price-conscious shoppers would flock to its stores.
item.dc:creator: Jordyn Holman
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers outside a Walmart in Teterboro, N.J., in April.

item.title: Delayed Jobs Data to Give Snapshot of a Labor Market Under Stress
item.description: Economists expect that employment growth was anemic in September, before the government shutdown delayed data collection.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Help! My Rental Car Died Within a Mile, and Avis Charged Me $1,367.
item.description: A visitor to Italy had to abandon an S.U.V. after it conked out just minutes from the rental agency. Then he got another surprise: a hefty repair bill.
item.dc:creator: Seth Kugel

item.title: Family Affair: Commerce Secretary’s Sons Cash In on A.I. Frenzy
item.description: Howard Lutnick is helping push data center projects. His family companies are profiting from them.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton, Michael Rothfeld, David Yaffe-Bellany and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mammoth data center is rising in Amarillo, Texas. Firms controlled by the Lutnick family have helped finance it, banking millions in fees in the process.

item.title: Holiday Hiring Slows, Frustrating Job Seekers
item.description: Retailers are adding fewer of the seasonal roles that many Americans rely on to make ends meet.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shoppers at a Target in Colonie, N.Y., last year on Black Friday. The retailer hasn’t said how many seasonal workers it plans to hire for this year’s holiday shopping period.

item.title: Is Scalp Care the New Big Beauty Trend?
item.description: Consumers are increasingly fixating on their scalps, turning to head spas, pricey treatments and products to combat thin hair and irritation.
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus
item.media:credit: Winnie Au for The New York Times
item.media:description: The focus on scalps “took time until people were finally interested in it, maybe five or six years ago, when American people started the self-care trend,” said Ritsuko Borges, the founder of the Japanese head spa Masa.Kanai in Manhattan.

item.title: California Has a Legal Clause for Housing That Could Put NIMBYs in a Corner
item.description: For years, the state has been nudging its cities to build housing to address a severe shortage. Maybe what they needed was a shove.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty and Gabriela Bhaskar
item.media:description: The lot on South Linden Drive in Beverly Hills where Mr. Pustilnikov has proposed an apartment tower and hotel.

item.title: As Sanctions on Russian Oil Loom, India Prepares to End Its Buying Spree
item.description: India has been snapping up discounted Russian crude for three years, but U.S. sanctions that take effect on Friday are expected to end the lucrative trade.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli
item.media:description: Oil pumpjacks outside Almetyevsk, Russia, in 2023.

item.title: Saudi Arabia, Once Shunned, Has Corporate Titans Swooning for Deals
item.description: Some of the most prominent U.S. executives gathered at the Kennedy Center for an event promoting deal-making with the oil-rich kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: President Trump posing next to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia for a group photo at the U.S.-Saudi Investment Forum at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

item.title: Stocks Tumble as Early Rally Gives Way to Tech Anxiety
item.description: After a week of market uneasiness, Nvidia’s profit surge and Walmart’s earnings had initially offered investors relief. But the bullishness faded by Thursday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Joe Rennison, Eshe Nelson and River Akira Davis
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Jensen Huang, chief executive of Nvidia, which had eased investors’ worries about potential A.I. overinvestment after the company reported earnings on Wednesday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Prince Has Big Plans, but His Giant Fund Is Low on Cash
item.description: After nearly a decade of expensive, hit-and-miss investments, Mohammed bin Salman is overseeing a behind-the-scenes restructuring of the kingdom’s all-important wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: President Trump welcomed Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia to the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Mexico Is Now the United States’ Top Buyer
item.description: For first time in at least 30 years, the United States has exported more to Mexico than Canada, U.S. government data show, in a sign of how much North American trade has consolidated.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Gabriel V. Cárdenas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trucks moving goods from the United States to Mexico in February. “Mexico is the United States’ main trading partner,” said Marcelo Ebrard, Mexico’s economy minister.

item.title: After Shutdown, Labor Department Says Some Data is Gone for Good
item.description: Surveys were delayed and some cannot be collected at all, officials said, further complicating the Federal Reserve’s decision on interest rates next month.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Incomplete data has major implications for central bank officials debating whether to lower interest rates for a third meeting in a row.

item.title: December Rate Cut in Doubt as Fed Fault Lines Deepen, Minutes Show
item.description: The central bank’s decision to lower interest rates last month was more divisive than it first appeared as officials splintered over how to weigh a weakening labor market against rising inflation.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said recently that officials at the central bank held “strongly differing views.”
